quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Every new person on the product team is acting like they work at Google and have these infinite resources and infinite time to make sure everything is perfect.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Highlights a common, costly mismatch between big-tech process expectations and the real constraints most teams operate under.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It became such this focus on the right way of doing product management that no one's taken any risk.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Warns that rigid adherence to “best practices” can unintentionally suppress experimentation and risk-taking.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: At Reforge, we're building frameworks that are tools in a toolkit. You pull them out when relevant. They're not a coloring book to stay inside the lines of.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Offers a practical mental model for using PM frameworks flexibly rather than as strict process rules.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our chat, we cover something he calls the zero interest rate phenomenon product manager and how to avoid that, what he's found works best when interviewing product managers, what impact he expects from GPT-4 on the role of product management, when to trust your instincts versus your team's insights and instincts, what are all the different kinds of network effects, and how do you effectively leverage them?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Previews several concrete frameworks and decision points practitioners can apply (e.g., interviewing, instincts vs. team input, network effects).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Get the right data, ask the right questions, get the right answers, and make growth happen.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Amplitude)
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable analytics workflow that links data quality to decision-making and growth outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but if there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern grow team stack, this leads to wasted time building internal tools or trying to run your experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: Highlights the hidden cost of poor tooling integration: teams lose velocity by rebuilding infrastructure or misusing the wrong tools.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved about our experimentation platform was being able to easily slice results by device, by country, and by user stage.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: A concrete example of an experimentation analysis method—segmentation—that helps teams find where effects differ across cohorts.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic clickthrough metrics and instead use your North Star metrics, like activation, retention, subscriptions, and payments.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Eppo)
quotes.context: Actionable measurement advice: optimize experiments against North Star outcomes rather than shallow engagement proxies.

quotes.topic_title: Casey’s current work and advising
quotes.text: I'm still spending some time with Whatnot and Eventbrite as  advisors. I stepped back from the CPO of Eventbrite in October, but still working on some long-term marketplace strategy stuff, some growth strategy stuff.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Shows a practical model for transitioning out of an exec role while still contributing via focused advisory work on strategy and growth.

quotes.topic_title: Casey’s current work and advising
quotes.text: I'm doing some angel investing in marketplaces in what I call tech debt as a service, which is what are startups that are building out things that were hard for my teams in the past to build or maintain inside previous companies?
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable investment/innovation lens—turning internal “hard-to-build” problems into startup opportunities (“tech debt as a service”).

quotes.topic_title: Casey’s current work and advising
quotes.text: Yeah. I always love seeing how I can help companies. Everyone should err on the side of reaching out and seeing if I have time to help, if there's something they think I can help with.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Actionable networking advice: default to outreach rather than self-rejecting when seeking help or collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: Casey’s current work and advising
quotes.text: I can't promise anything, but yeah, I just love talking to people about this stuff.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A realistic expectation-setting line practitioners can use when offering help without overcommitting.

quotes.topic_title: Why the CPO role is so hard
quotes.text: I think it's very hard to keep product-market fit as a CPO within a company for a long time. The needs of the business shift over time, and of course, we all have different strengths and weaknesses in our game.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Highlights a core mental model for CPO longevity: your fit with the company changes as the business evolves, so you must continually reassess alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Why the CPO role is so hard
quotes.text: In general, as an executive, it's just impossible to do everything perfectly, and any little misstep, mistake, or something you just missed can blow up in a major way.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that executive roles are high-variance: small errors can have outsized consequences, so risk management matters as much as execution.

quotes.topic_title: Why the CPO role is so hard
quotes.text: Frequently, CEOs have visions that can change and get misaligned with the product leader.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Points to CEO alignment as a key failure mode for CPOs and a practical area to proactively manage through constant calibration.

quotes.topic_title: Why the CPO role is so hard
quotes.text: Also, with leadership roles, you don't get put on a PIP. If a CEO loses confidence, it's over immediately.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Actionable insight about executive accountability: confidence is the currency, and there may be no formal warning period to recover.

quotes.topic_title: Why the CPO role is so hard
quotes.text: I started to see that the areas of leverage for a product leader were just less in my wheelhouse over time. I just talked to my boss about it, and we worked out something where I continue to advise on the things that I'm uniquely good at, and find other people who are better at some of these other things that were maybe more important at the time.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Provides a concrete playbook for adapting when role demands shift: renegotiate scope to focus on unique strengths and bring in complementary leaders.

quotes.topic_title: How to survive and succeed as CPO
quotes.text: The first one I can think of is a big change from being a product leader to a CPO or something equivalent is you're actually a company exec first and a product exec second.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A reframing of the CPO role that prioritizes enterprise leadership over functional leadership.

quotes.topic_title: How to survive and succeed as CPO
quotes.text: You have to not only truly care, but create the perception that you care about sales, about marketing, about legal, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Practical advice on building cross-functional credibility by managing both substance and perception.

quotes.topic_title: How to survive and succeed as CPO
quotes.text: I think something else is really trying to diagnose, without as much bias as possible, where are the strengths and weaknesses of your team? Where are the strengths and weaknesses of your product? Lay that out with your peers and say, "Here's where we are. Here's where I think we need to go. Here's the timeline on which I'm going to work to get us there."
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for aligning executives by explicitly assessing reality, direction, and timing.

quotes.topic_title: How to survive and succeed as CPO
quotes.text: Because I think product's such a confusing discipline for people who aren't in it, like a sales leader, many CEOs, a marketing leader, that they don't necessarily know what great looks like.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Explains why product leaders must proactively educate peers on what “good” and “great” mean in product work.

quotes.topic_title: How to survive and succeed as CPO
quotes.text: Just forcing you to write it all down is really helpful, but then it forces you to explain it.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A simple operating mechanism—written narratives—that improves clarity and executive alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Zero interest rate phenomenon product managers
quotes.text: My feedback would be like, no, user research is a scarce resource. We have to reserve it for the areas that have extreme uncertainty and high leverage for getting to certain, so if you're redesigning the login page for Eventbrite, you don't need to use that resource to learn what to do. Just go see what FANG and the top unicorns did.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for allocating research effort: treat research as scarce and use competitive patterns for low-uncertainty problems.

quotes.topic_title: Zero interest rate phenomenon product managers
quotes.text: I think we sort of forgot in the industry that many times, the fastest way to learn is to ship, so that if you actually get them to skip research and just go look at competitors, another thing I was noticing is I'd get a list of options other companies have done, but there would be no analysis of why those companies chose different options and what's most applicable for us.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A counterweight to over-research: ship to learn, and when borrowing patterns, analyze the underlying rationale and fit.

quotes.topic_title: Zero interest rate phenomenon product managers
quotes.text: At Reforge, we're building frameworks that are tools in a toolkit. You pull them out when relevant. They're not a coloring book to stay inside the lines of.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for using frameworks flexibly rather than as rigid process.

quotes.topic_title: Zero interest rate phenomenon product managers
quotes.text: There's no framework that allows you to not use your brain at this company and just follow some sort of process for success in this profession.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A blunt reminder that judgment and thinking can’t be replaced by process—especially in constrained environments.

quotes.topic_title: Zero interest rate phenomenon product managers
quotes.text: Then my follow-up, which I don't ask, but what I really want to ask is like, "When's the last time you used your brain versus followed a process someone else designed at your company?" Because I want the former, not the latter.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A sharp interview lens for assessing decision-making under uncertainty versus process-following.

quotes.topic_title: When to use research vs ship to learn
quotes.text: you have to understand that the job is not to follow the process. The job is not to learn every framework possible. The job is to figure out how to add value to customers that translates into value to the business. Just reorient your North Star, if you've gotten away from that.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A crisp reminder that frameworks are tools, not the goal—value creation is the real north star for PMs.

quotes.topic_title: When to use research vs ship to learn
quotes.text: When I joined Eventbrite, there was this team that didn't ship anything in a quarter.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A concrete example of how over-indexing on process/research can stall delivery and learning.

quotes.topic_title: When to use research vs ship to learn
quotes.text: The more scale you have tends to be you have less sophisticated customers because you're generally like a consumer thing where the customers are rational. They're not experts. That's generally where you just try things. You measure the impact they have, and you only really bring in USEARCH, research when the impact seems confusing, but you can run experiments. You can get data really easily, so bias towards getting stuff out there and seeing what users respond to.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A practical heuristic: consumer/scale products should default to shipping and experimentation, using research mainly to explain confusing results.

quotes.topic_title: When to use research vs ship to learn
quotes.text: If you're super enterprise, it's the opposite. Each customer, first off, is sophisticated and tend to be rational. They're paying you like six figures or more, and you could talk to the customers and sales, who knows the customers really well directly, and they tell you want they want. They tell you what they're willing to pay for. You build it. They pay you. Bing, bang, boom.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A contrasting model for enterprise: direct customer and sales input can be the primary “research” loop tied to willingness to pay.

quotes.topic_title: When to use research vs ship to learn
quotes.text: If research is going to be a scarce resource inside the company, which I think it will in most places, you have to figure out where it's a high-leverage area, which means either really big problem, we don't understand it well enough, or we know the problem's big. We understand it well, but we're just not sure if our solution's going to, in any way, hit the mark.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A prioritization rule for allocating limited research capacity to the highest-uncertainty, highest-impact bets.

quotes.topic_title: Whatnot overview and interviewing PMs
quotes.text: I feel like the whole thing's gotten so performative. It's like interviewing is handing out Oscars based on who's prepared the best tell me about a time response, versus actually assessing who can do the job we're hiring for. It's like most PMs are better PM interviewers than PMs now.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A contrarian critique of modern PM interviews that argues rehearsed storytelling can crowd out real job-skill assessment.

quotes.topic_title: Whatnot overview and interviewing PMs
quotes.text: I don't ask about your work history. I don't care about your perfectly practiced answers. I'm going to give you real scenarios that I expect from the role. I want to hear how you'd approach them.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A practical interviewing methodology: use realistic role scenarios to evaluate how candidates think and operate.

quotes.topic_title: Whatnot overview and interviewing PMs
quotes.text: If you can't come up with a few reasonable ideas, figure out how to test them quickly without analyst support or research, I'm just not interested.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Sets a clear bar for PM effectiveness: generate hypotheses and design fast tests even with limited resources.

quotes.topic_title: Whatnot overview and interviewing PMs
quotes.text: Some things I pay attention to is if they're talking about solutions that are going to take a long time to get signal from, whether it's months and months of engineering time before you actually see the impact on users or the business, I think that's always great.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Highlights a key evaluation lens: prefer approaches that produce measurable signal sooner rather than after long build cycles.

quotes.topic_title: Whatnot overview and interviewing PMs
quotes.text: If they're not factoring in the amount of time it will take, in general, is not a good sign, and not thinking a bit more holistically about the types of metrics they expect to improve versus track to make sure they haven't gone down.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A red-flag checklist for PM thinking: time-to-signal and balanced metric impact (wins plus guardrails).

quotes.topic_title: AI and the future of product management
quotes.text: Well, I think if you thought the PM job was just filling in the latest Reforge or Shreyas framework, and then getting that automatic FANG promotion every year and a half, then yeah, you're going to get replaced by AI.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that PMs who reduce the role to templated frameworks are most vulnerable to AI automation.

quotes.topic_title: AI and the future of product management
quotes.text: I think the real PM job is the least likely to get replaced over time because you need real subject matter expertise. You need to be trading off a lot of different types of things, and making good decisions for the company and for your customers.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Defines a durable mental model of PM value: domain expertise plus multi-factor tradeoffs and decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: AI and the future of product management
quotes.text: It's a tool that's trained on sounding smart rather than always necessarily being smart.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for calibrating trust in current-gen AI outputs in product work.

quotes.topic_title: AI and the future of product management
quotes.text: I said, "All right. Let's just do it on your screen," so she did and my bio said I started my career at Google, and worked on Google Trends, and a bunch of other products, none of which happened. It was just complete nonsense.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Concrete example of AI hallucination that illustrates why PMs should be cautious using AI for high-stakes facts.

quotes.topic_title: AI and the future of product management
quotes.text: I think where I'm more inclined for PMs to try to get leverage out of something like GPT-4 is a lot of the tedious work that's maybe not their specialty to begin with.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on using AI for low-risk, time-saving tasks rather than core PM judgment.

quotes.topic_title: Founder intuition versus team expertise
quotes.text: I think that's actually the opposite of what you want, because none of these people know the business as well as you get it. You actually need to direct them until they show you they've really got it and are making better decisions than you would.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Contrarian guidance for founders: don’t delegate too early—lead until new hires demonstrably outperform your judgment.

quotes.topic_title: Founder intuition versus team expertise
quotes.text: After a month or so, she was like, "Dude, you're in all my meetings. I got this." That let me know she was in a different part of the situational leadership framework than I had put her in, so I backed away, and she crushed it from there.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Concrete example of using “situational leadership” signals to calibrate when to step back and delegate.

quotes.topic_title: Founder intuition versus team expertise
quotes.text: I encourage employees to proactively signal both directions, like, "Hey, I need direction from you." Or, "Hey, I got it from here. Trust me on this one."
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Actionable advice for employees on how to manage up by explicitly requesting guidance or claiming ownership when ready.

quotes.topic_title: Founder intuition versus team expertise
quotes.text: When you're finding product-market fit, everything goes through the founders. You cannot outsource that.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A clear phase-based rule: founder-led decision-making is mandatory during product-market fit discovery.

quotes.topic_title: Founder intuition versus team expertise
quotes.text: Everything was not moving as quickly because everything had to go through the same person to get done.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A cautionary scaling lesson: centralized founder approval becomes a bottleneck that slows execution.

quotes.topic_title: Influencing founders and handling disagreement
quotes.text: Different founders have different forms of feedback they listen to. It might be talking to other CEOs, or other operators, or trusted advisors, certain customers. Some might be very data-oriented, so you just run the experiment and ask for forgiveness after you proved it works, whatever. Everyone's got a different thing they respond to. You try to figure out what actually influences the CEO and build that case, whether it's through an experiment, the right customer intro, the right external advisor.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A practical framework for influencing a founder: identify what evidence they trust and tailor your pushback to that channel.

quotes.topic_title: Influencing founders and handling disagreement
quotes.text: If they rebuke that as well, then you got to disagree and commit, or find a new company to join, or start your own. Like I said, it's their company. They can make the call.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Clear decision tree for what to do after you’ve made your best case and still get overruled.

quotes.topic_title: Influencing founders and handling disagreement
quotes.text: I didn't come from Facebook or Google like most of the other people, or Pinterest. No one gave a shit about Chicago startups at the time, so when they didn't trust my proposals, I just went and talked to the heads of growth at all the startups they did respect. I talked to Dropbox, I talked to Facebook. When they said all the same things I was saying but I said that they said it, not me, that was, sadly, more convincing.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A concrete tactic for overcoming credibility gaps: borrow authority via respected external validators.

quotes.topic_title: Influencing founders and handling disagreement
quotes.text: In the long run, it ended up being quite necessary because of the innovations around DoorDash, and Postmates, and later, Uber Eats having their own delivery network and us needing to counter that.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Example of a founder being right on longer-term strategy—building capabilities early to match future competitive shifts.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With their new Ahrefs webmaster tools, you can optimize your personal website like a professional for free.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical, low-cost way for individuals to apply professional-grade SEO optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can scan your website for over a hundred common SEO issues that might be hurting your performance in search engines, plus get advice on how to fix those errors.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: run an audit to identify specific SEO problems and follow guided fixes.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can have it automatically browse your website's internal and external links and get actionable insights from your backlink profiles, and you can learn what keywords your website ranks for and see how you stack up against your competitors.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete workflow for improving SEO via link analysis, backlink insights, and competitive keyword benchmarking.

quotes.topic_title: Network effects: types and how they evolve
quotes.text: Yeah, so at it's core, a network effect is when a product or a business gets better with more users or customers using it.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A crisp, reusable definition practitioners can apply to evaluate whether a product truly has network effects.

quotes.topic_title: Network effects: types and how they evolve
quotes.text: There's three types that I tend to focus on.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Introduces a simple taxonomy that helps teams diagnose and design network-effect-driven growth and defensibility.

quotes.topic_title: Network effects: types and how they evolve
quotes.text: The thing that's really tricky in understanding social networks is they're traditionally described as these direct network effect businesses, but all of them have to become either cross-side and/or data and network effect businesses over time.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Challenges the common belief that social networks are “just” direct network effects and frames evolution as inevitable.

quotes.topic_title: Network effects: types and how they evolve
quotes.text: The only companies that stay direct network effect businesses are these pure communication tools like Messenger, iMessage, WhatsApp. There isn't a clear path to make money with those, but you want to sell ads, you're becoming a cross-side network effect business.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Connects monetization strategy to network-effect type, offering a practical lens for product and business model decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Network effects: types and how they evolve
quotes.text: I think they're a great form of defensibility, first off. Do they make sense for every business? No, but in a lot of cases, in order for you to evolve properly and continue to grow, they can become a necessity.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on when to invest in additional network effects: not always, but often required for sustained growth.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace examples and Grubhub disruption setup
quotes.text: I think people do mistake any form of network effect as this perfect form of defensibility. They're the best form of defensibility, but that doesn't mean they're immune to disruption.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that network effects are strong but not absolute protection, shaping how practitioners think about competitive risk.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace examples and Grubhub disruption setup
quotes.text: I think the main way this happens with cross-side network effects that we typically talk about for marketplaces is when a disruptor dramatically expands selection.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A practical disruption model for marketplaces: competitors can break network effects by expanding selection via new supply strategies.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace examples and Grubhub disruption setup
quotes.text: But one important thing to remember is Grubhub was an asset-light marketplace model. Restaurants did their own delivery through their own delivery drivers that they hired.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Highlights a key strategic constraint of asset-light marketplaces that can become a vulnerability when the market shifts.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace examples and Grubhub disruption setup
quotes.text: in that you really need to be comprehensive or have exclusive inventory, and Grubhub strived to be comprehensive.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: A clear supply-side strategy framework (comprehensive vs. exclusive) that operators can use to evaluate marketplace positioning.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace examples and Grubhub disruption setup
quotes.text: We call this a heavily managed marketplace model, as you are now facilitating the transaction versus just connecting buyers and sellers and taking payments like Grubhub did.
quotes.speaker: Casey Winters
quotes.context: Defines the operational shift from a lightweight connector to a managed marketplace—useful for deciding when to vertically integrate.
